# The HOPE Study {.unnumbered}

**H**ealth **O**utcomes in **P**regnancy and **E**arly Childhood

## Overview

The HOPE Study is a planned longitudinal, observational study of mother-infant dyads, aiming to understand how genetics, environment, and behavior will impact the health of women during and after pregnancy, as well as the health of children in American Samoa. The study focuses on gestational diabetes (a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy) and its influence on child body size and growth.

## Planned genomic data

-   CREBRF rs373863828
-   Genome-wide DNA methylation data
-   Genome-wide RNA seq data
-   Microbiome data
-   PFAS data

## Eligibility

The study includes mothers who are over 18 years old, at least 35 weeks pregnant, planning to give birth at LBJ Hospital in American Samoa, and intending to reside in American Samoa for at least 6 months post-birth.

## Study Dates

This study is in progress, recruitment phase! 

## Ethics

This study is approved by the Institutional Review Boards at the University of Pittsburgh, Yale University, and the American Samoa Department of Health, as well as the Lyndon B. Johnson Tropical Medical Center (American Samoa) Research Oversight Committee. 

## Assessments

Trained, bilingual Samoan research assistants conduct assessments at various time points: before birth, immediately post-birth, and at 2, 4, and 6 months post-birth. Data collection includes sleep, nutrition, behavior, environment, social determinants of health, and physical growth measurements. Biospecimens such as saliva, stool, umbilical cord blood, and capillary blood are collected.
